questions.answerB: Help the other driver by moving to the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Ride in the center portion of your lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the left portion of your lane
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Riding on the side nearest to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision. Riding on the side farthest from the passing vehicle is also dangerous because it may tempt them to merge back into your lane too soon. Stay in the center portion of the lane when being passed.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerB: Identifying hazards and prioritizing risks.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: When riding in a lane of traffic, a motorcycle operator:
questions.answerA: Should always ride in the same part of the lane.
questions.answerB: Should vary their lane position according to riding conditions.
questions.answerC: Should always ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerD: Should always ride in the left part of the lane.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. Vary your lane position based on changing road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Riding alongside another rider:
questions.answerA: Allows you to maximize the surface of the road.
questions.answerB: Should be avoided because it limits your escape routes.
questions.answerC: Allows you to communicate with one another.
questions.answerD: Makes it easier for other motorists to pass.
questions.explanation: You should not ride alongside another motorcyclist because doing so will limit both of your possible routes of escape if you encounter a hazard.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Keep your intentions hidden from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.answerC: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerD: Be close to the road signs.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is discouraged because:
questions.answerA: You may have a difficult time getting to a highway exit.
questions.answerB: You may be in the other vehicle’s blind spot.
questions.answerC: You may block the driver's view.
questions.answerD: It prevents other drivers from passing both of you.
questions.explanation: Riding alongside another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. The driver may enter your lane without warning if they can't see you. The vehicle will also block your route of escape if a hazard arises.

questions.question: The control for the rear brake is usually located:
questions.answerB: On the left handlebar.
questions.answerC: Near the left foot.
questions.answerD: Near the right foot.
questions.explanation: The rear brake of a motorcycle is usually operated with the right foot.

questions.question: What can you do to increase your chances of being seen at an intersection?
questions.answerB: Swerve within your lane to draw attention to your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Raise your arms.
questions.answerD: Avoid using your brakes.
questions.explanation: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, use your headlight and ride in a lane position that creates the best view of oncoming traffic. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle that allows you to take evasive action.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Not wear a jacket if it's warm out.
questions.answerB: Always wear a jacket, even if it’s warm out.
questions.answerC: Wear shorts in warm weather.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about long shoelaces.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should always wear a long-sleeved jacket made of appropriate material when riding. This is true even in warm weather because wearing a jacket is important to help prevent dehydration. You should also always wear long pants, and tuck in the laces of your footwear to prevent them from catching on the motorcycle.

questions.question: A major effect of alcohol consumption is:
questions.answerB: The slowing down of bodily functions.
questions.answerC: Increasing nervousness.
questions.answerD: Increasing alertness.
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a depressant. It slows down and impairs bodily functions, both physical and mental.

questions.question: Where is the greatest potential for conflict between a motorcycle and other traffic?
questions.answerB: Highways
questions.answerC: Parking lots
questions.answerD: Residential areas
questions.explanation: The greatest potential for conflict between your motorcycle and other traffic is at intersections. Be extra alert when riding somewhere where another vehicle may cross in front of your path of travel.

questions.question: Motorists entering a highway from an entrance ramp to your right may not see your motorcycle. To help the entering drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Flash your lights.
questions.answerC: Move to the left portion of your lane so they can share the lane, if necessary.
questions.answerD: Move into another lane, if necessary.
questions.explanation: Give plenty of room to vehicles merging onto a highway from an entrance ramp. Merge into a lane farther away from the entrance ramp, if necessary. If it is not possible to change lanes, adjust your speed to allow room for the vehicle to safely enter the highway.

questions.question: If your front tire locks while braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the brake engaged until you come to a full stop.
questions.answerB: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.answerC: Release the brake lever and use only the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release the brake lever until the tire regains traction.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks while braking, you should release the brake lever until the tire regains traction and re-apply the brake.

questions.question: It is best to not ride directly alongside another vehicle because:
questions.answerA: You may be riding in its blind spot.
questions.answerB: It is distracting to have a vehicle next to you.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may want to use the lane.
questions.answerD: It would be difficult to see what is happening behind you.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to ride directly alongside a vehicle in another lane because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot and the driver will have no way of knowing you are there. It can also be dangerous because the vehicle may block your path of escape if another hazard arises.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator:
questions.answerB: Is about to stop.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerB: Occasionally
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: Helmeted riders are ________ more likely to survive than those not wearing helmets at the time of a crash.
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Eight times
questions.answerD: Ten times
questions.explanation: At any speed, wearing a helmet will make you three times more likely to survive head injuries in the event of a crash than you would if not wearing a helmet.

questions.question: Brightly-colored helmets:
questions.answerA: May make it easier for the wearer to be seen.
questions.answerB: Can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Don’t help to improve a rider's visibility.
questions.answerD: Are not permitted.
questions.explanation: Choosing a brightly-colored helmet is recommended. Not only will the helmet protect you in the case of a crash, but the bright color of the helmet will help other road users see you.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield protects the wearer from:
questions.answerB: Headlight glare.
questions.answerC: Noise.
questions.answerD: Sunshine.
questions.explanation: In addition to protecting your face from injury in a crash, a face shield protects you from wind, dust, dirt, rain, insects, and pebbles thrown up from surrounding vehicles.

questions.question: A larger cushion of space may not be necessary if:
questions.answerB: You cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Weather and traffic conditions are perfect.
questions.answerD: Traffic is heavy.
questions.explanation: Your following distance should be larger than usual when you are traveling under imperfect conditions. Increase your following distance if pavement is slippery, you can't see through the vehicle in front of you, or traffic is heavy.

questions.question: If you find yourself riding alongside another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerB: Wave at the other driver.
questions.answerC: Stay alongside the vehicle until the next exit and then exit.
questions.answerD: Let the other driver worry about it.
questions.explanation: Riding directly next to another vehicle is dangerous because you could be riding in the vehicle's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle may block your route of escape if another hazard arises. If you find yourself riding directly alongside another vehicle, either speed up or drop back.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: When being passed from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Activate your turn signal.
questions.explanation: When you are being passed from behind or by an oncoming vehicle, stay in the center portion of your lane. Riding any closer to the passing vehicle can put you in danger.

questions.question: To effectively provide protection for a motorcycle rider, pants should:
questions.answerA: Be made of a soft material.
questions.answerB: Be made of a heavy material.
questions.answerC: Fit loosely enough that they flap in the wind.
questions.answerD: Be short and expose some parts of the legs.
questions.explanation: For your protection, you should wear pants that cover your entire legs and are made of leather or another sturdy synthetic material. Clothing should fit snugly enough that it does not flap in the wind but not so snugly that it restricts your movement.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: When braking on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use abrupt pressure on the front brake to prevent locking the front tire.
questions.answerC: Only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use either brake, but use only one brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should use both brakes to slow down. Squeeze the brake lever gradually to avoid locking the front wheel and use gentle pressure on the rear brake.

questions.question: You will ______ hear a tire going flat.
questions.answerB: Usually
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: Seldom
questions.explanation: Motorcycle riders will rarely actually hear a tire going flat. Tire failure is more often indicated by a change in how the motorcycle handles.

questions.question: A motorcyclist is well-protected if they are wearing:
questions.answerA: A jacket that allows the arms to be exposed.
questions.answerB: Boots with tall heels.
questions.answerC: Leather gloves.
questions.answerD: Shoes that stop below their ankle.
questions.explanation: For your protection while riding, it is best to wear a jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely. Boots or shoes should be tall and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles. Footwear should have low heels that will not catch on the foot pegs or rough road surfaces. Gloves made of leather or another durable material will help protect your hands in the event of a crash while providing you with an improved grip on the controls.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerB: General wear
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: When making an ordinary stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerB: Use only the rear brake to save the front brake for special situations.
questions.answerC: Use only the front brake to save the rear brake for special situations.
questions.answerD: Sharply squeeze the front brake only.
questions.explanation: Develop the habit of using both brakes every time you slow or stop. If you need to stop quickly, it is best to apply both brakes. It will be easier to apply both brakes in a quick stop if you have already developed this habit.

questions.question: How many alcoholic drinks need to be consumed before a rider may begin to feel the effects?
questions.answerB: Three to four
questions.answerC: Six
questions.answerD: More than eight
questions.explanation: As little as one alcoholic drink can affect a person's ability to ride. It is both illegal and dangerous to ride a motorcycle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Keep an expanded cushion of space between your motorcycle and the vehicle in front of you:
questions.answerA: When conditions will make stopping more difficult than usual.
questions.answerB: When you want to look at the scenery.
questions.answerC: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.answerD: To prevent the driver in front of you from knowing you are there.
questions.explanation: An expanded cushion of space is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a larger following distance.

questions.question: If you must swerve, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn your handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Protect your lane from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Allow you a nice view of scenery.
questions.answerC: Place you in other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerD: Hide your intentions from other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a benefit of riding in a close group?
questions.answerA: It takes up minimal space on the highway.
questions.answerB: The group is easy to see.
questions.answerC: The group is unlikely to be split up.
questions.answerD: The riders will get to their destination more quickly in a close group than a group that is spread out.
questions.explanation: Riding in close ranks is recommended over riding in a group that is spread out because the group will take up less space on the road, be easier for others to see, and be less likely to get separated at traffic lights and during passes.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the motorcycle is as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Assume other drivers can’t see you.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with taking steps to ensure that other drivers see you.
questions.answerD: Ride offensively.
questions.explanation: Because motorcycles are small in stature and have fewer and smaller lights than other vehicles, they can be difficult to see. For your safety, it is best to ride defensively and assume that others on the road do not see you.

questions.question: When riding a three-wheeled motorcycle through a curve, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Stay in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Stay on the outside of the lane.
questions.answerC: Change your path as needed.
questions.answerD: Use the shoulder.
questions.explanation: The cornering characteristics of a three-wheeled motorcycle or a motorcycle with a sidecar differ from those of a two-wheeled motorcycle. The best path for a three-wheeler to take through a curve may not actually follow the curve. For example, you may need to move from the outside of the curve to the inside of the curve before straightening out your path.

questions.question: To receive maximum protection, wear a helmet that is certified by the:
questions.answerB: Federal Trade Commission.
questions.answerC: Federal Transportation Network.
questions.answerD: National Association of Helmets.
questions.explanation: To get maximum protection, use a motorcycle helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) standards.

questions.question: To be effective, an eye or face shield should be all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Resistant to penetration.
questions.answerC: Able to fasten securely.
questions.answerD: Airtight.
questions.explanation: To be effective, eye protection and face shields must be free of scratches; be resistant to penetration; give a clear view to either side; fasten securely; permit air to pass through; and permit enough room for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath.

questions.question: Passengers should:
questions.answerB: Never come into contact with the operator.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on their seat as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto their seat.
questions.explanation: Before riding while carrying a passenger, you should instruct your passenger to lean with you through turns and curves. They should hold onto your waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When looking through a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn both your head and your shoulders to get a better look.
questions.answerB: Turn just your head, not your shoulders.
questions.answerC: Use only your mirrors.
questions.answerD: Only move your eyes, not your head.
questions.explanation: When turning, look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: Before changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head to check for vehicles in your blind spot.
questions.answerB: Rely on your mirrors to show you all of your surroundings.
questions.answerC: Point in the direction of the lane change.
questions.answerD: Speed up to get ahead of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots, just like any other vehicle. You should always turn your head to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes. Do not rely on your mirrors alone.

questions.question: To get the best protection, be sure that your helmet:
questions.answerB: Looks sturdy.
questions.answerC: Is inexpensive.
questions.answerD: Is in your favorite color.
questions.explanation: Choose a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards. It should fit you snugly all the way around and be free of obvious defects.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerB: Lean when the operator leans.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: Your motorcycle’s brake light is:
questions.answerA: More noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerB: Less noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerC: Less important than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerD: More easily seen than a car’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: The brake light of a motorcycle is usually not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car. Flashing your brake light before slowing or stopping can help other drivers notice that you are about to brake.

questions.question: Swerving a motorcycle:
questions.answerB: Requires little traction.
questions.answerC: Is a slow maneuver.
questions.answerD: Should be done to avoid a hazard on a slippery road.
questions.explanation: Swerving is a quick maneuver that requires a lot of traction in order to be safely executed. Making sudden moves, such as swerving, on slippery surfaces should be avoided.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Always avoid the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Always avoid the right portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Always avoid the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerD: Use whichever portion of the lane is safest.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that you always need to avoid. Adjust your position in response to changing conditions on the road.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: To be effective, a face shield should not:
questions.answerB: Allow clear views to both sides.
questions.answerC: Be airtight.
questions.answerD: Fasten securely.
questions.explanation: An effective face shield should be free of scratches, be resistant to penetration, allow clear views to both sides, fasten securely, permit air to pass through, and provide enough space for eyeglasses or sunglasses to be worn underneath. It is important for a face shield to permit the passage of air because an airtight face shield can create fogging and make it difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: Which formation is best for keeping the riders in a group close together?
questions.answerB: Staggered
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When making a turn:
questions.answerA: There is less traction available for stopping.
questions.answerB: There is more traction available for stopping.
questions.answerC: Stopping is no different than making a stop on a straightaway.
questions.answerD: Stopping should never be attempted.
questions.explanation: It is possible to brake while turning, but it should be done with great care. When a motorcycle is leaning to turn, there is less traction available for stopping because some of the traction is being used for turning.

questions.question: The primary source of information about your motorcycle should come from:
questions.answerB: The owner’s manual.
questions.answerC: A library book about motorcycles.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle enthusiast.
questions.explanation: The owner's manual should be your primary source of information about your specific type of motorcycle. Be sure to read the manual before operating your motorcycle for the first time.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: Both brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.answerD: Only one brake, front or rear, should be used.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. Always apply the brakes simultaneously.

questions.question: If wearing footwear with laces, the laces:
questions.answerB: Should hang loose.
questions.answerC: Should be taken off of the footwear.
questions.answerD: Should be glued together.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should securely tuck in the laces of your footwear so that they will not catch on your motorcycle.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When being passed, all of the following are potential hazards, except:
questions.answerB: Objects being thrown from other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Blasts of wind.
questions.answerD: Headlights.
questions.explanation: When being passed, motorcyclists should be careful not to be hit by any part of the passing vehicle, including its mirrors. In addition to the vehicle itself, motorcyclists should be aware of wind gusts coming from the passing vehicle and potential objects being thrown by a passenger in the vehicle who may not be paying attention to the road.

questions.question: Which of the following will help you ride safely on slippery surfaces?
questions.answerB: Using both brakes
questions.answerC: Using the center lane
questions.answerD: Maintaining or increasing your speed
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, reduce your speed, brake using both brakes, and avoid sudden moves. Avoid the center of the lane and instead follow tire tracks left by cars. Always keep an eye out for hazards that may make a road surface especially slippery, such as oil spots and loose gravel.

questions.question: During your pre-ride inspection, you should check all of the following, except the:
questions.answerB: Headlight and taillight.
questions.answerC: Turn signals.
questions.answerD: Reflectors.
questions.explanation: Before setting off on any ride, you should do a thorough check of your motorcycle. Inspect the tires, oil and fluid levels, headlight, tail light, turn signals, brake light, clutch and throttle, mirrors, brakes, and horn.

questions.question: Riding at night is usually:
questions.answerA: Easier than riding during the day because you can more easily see the lights of other vehicles.
questions.answerB: More difficult than riding during the day because it is harder to see.
questions.answerC: Not allowed on highways.
questions.answerD: Less distracting than riding during the day.
questions.explanation: Riding safely at night is challenging because it is harder to see and be seen than it is during the day. The absence of normal shadows and light contrasts makes it harder to judge distances.

questions.question: A child passenger:
questions.answerA: Should be placed in front of the operator.
questions.answerB: Should be placed behind the operator.
questions.answerC: Does not have to be able to reach the footrests.
questions.answerD: Should hold onto the motorcycle frame.
questions.explanation: A child passenger on a motorcycle should always ride immediately behind the operator. A child sitting in front may be unable to balance properly and could interfere with the operator's use of the controls.

questions.question: When someone follows you too closely, you should:
questions.answerB: Not worry about them and just focus on the road in front of you.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder and let them pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger. Never ride on the shoulder of a road because drivers will never expect you to be there and may leave the road suddenly.

questions.question: To lean a motorcycle when making a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Always press on the left handgrip.
questions.answerB: Always press on the right handgrip.
questions.answerC: Press on the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To turn, a motorcycle must lean. To make the motorcycle lean, press on the handgrip in the direction of the turn.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking alcohol and wants to drive, which of the following should you not do?
questions.answerA: Encourage friends to talk them out of driving.
questions.answerB: Arrange for other transportation.
questions.answerC: Tell them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerD: Slow their pace of drinking.
questions.explanation: There are several strategies you can use to prevent someone from driving while under the influence of alcohol. You can arrange another way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow their pace of drinking, use any available excuse to stop them from leaving before they are sober, and get other friends involved to intervene as a group.

questions.question: A good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Ignore them.
questions.answerC: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerD: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: To swerve, you should:
questions.answerB: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: To swerve, apply a small amount of pressure to the handgrip located on the side of your intended direction of escape. To swerve to the left, press the left handgrip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handgrip, then the left.

questions.question: Helmets are:
questions.answerB: Required only for motorcycle operators under age 21.
questions.answerC: Required only for motorcycle operators who have held their license for a year or less.
questions.answerD: Not required, but recommended.
questions.explanation: In Maryland, anyone operating or riding a motorcycle must wear protective headgear that meets federal standards. A helmet is a rider's best protection against head or neck injury in the event of an accident.

questions.question: Before mounting your motorcycle, perform all of the following checks, except:
questions.answerB: Checking the oil level.
questions.answerC: Trying both brake controls to ensure the brake light activates.
questions.answerD: Ensuring that the paint is not scratched.
questions.explanation: Before riding, you should check the pressure and condition of your tires; check the oil and fluid levels; and make sure that the low beam headlight, high beam headlight, taillight, signal lights, and brake light all work properly.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes involve riders with little experience on their motorcycle.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: When riding at night, a motorcyclist should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerB: Three seconds.
questions.answerC: Four seconds.
questions.answerD: Five seconds.
questions.explanation: Because it is more difficult to see and judge distances in the dark than in daylight, you should maintain an expanded following distance of at least three seconds when riding at night. It may take you longer than usual to realize the vehicle in front of you has stopped and you may need additional time to slow or stop to avoid hitting the vehicle.

questions.question: When riding in a group, the best way to keep ranks close while maintaining an adequate safety cushion is to ride:
questions.answerB: In a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: In a single-file line.
questions.answerD: In a passing formation.
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is the best way to keep ranks close while still maintaining an adequate space cushion for all riders. Ride in a single-file line when riding in curves, turning, or entering or leaving a highway. Never ride side-by-side with another rider.

questions.question: Lane sharing is:
questions.answerB: Encouraged, but only when the roadway is congested.
questions.answerC: Allowed if you are carrying a passenger.
questions.answerD: Prohibited.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles require the width of a full lane to operate safely. Lane sharing is prohibited by law in Maryland.

questions.question: Where is the front brake lever usually located?
questions.answerB: On the right handgrip
questions.answerC: By the left foot peg
questions.answerD: By the right foot peg
questions.explanation: The front brake lever is generally located on the right handgrip. Make sure that you are aware of the locations of all your motorcycle's controls before beginning to ride.

questions.question: When riding in rain or fog, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your low beam headlight.
questions.answerC: Not use your headlight.
questions.answerD: Alternate between your headlight's low and high beam settings.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in snowy, rainy, or foggy weather. A high beam headlight can reflect off of these conditions and make it more difficult for a rider to see.

questions.question: You should choose the lane position that can:
questions.answerA: Minimize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerB: Maximize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerC: Maximize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow others to pass you.
questions.answerD: Minimize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow you to closely follow another vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: A helmet should not:
questions.answerB: Fit snugly.
questions.answerC: Be without obvious defects.
questions.answerD: Have been previously worn in an accident.
questions.explanation: You will get the greatest amount of protection from a helmet if it meets U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and state standards, fits snugly all the way around, and has no obvious defects. A helmet worn at the time of a crash should be replaced.

questions.question: To swerve correctly:
questions.answerB: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.explanation: To execute a swerve, press the handgrip on the side of your desired turn. Press on the opposite handgrip to return to your original direction after you are clear of the hazard.

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: The front brake supplies approximately how much of a motorcycle's potential stopping power?
questions.answerB: About 50 percent
questions.answerC: About 70 percent
questions.answerD: About 95 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. The front brake supplies at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: Which vest or jacket color would best help you to be seen?
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Silver
questions.answerD: Blue
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will increase your chances of being seen. Bright oranges, yellows, reds, or greens are best and are preferable to drab or dark colors.

questions.question: What is often found in the center portion of the lane?
questions.answerB: An oily or greasy strip
questions.answerC: Lane markings
questions.answerD: Ice
questions.explanation: Drippings from cars tend to form an oily strip in the center of each lane. Unless conditions are wet, it is usually still safe for a motorcycle to operate on the center strip.

questions.question: If in a no passing zone:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle may still pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle is not allowed to pass another vehicle.
questions.answerC: A motorcycle may pass another vehicle if the pass can be completed before another vehicle approaches.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle may pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Passing is prohibited in no passing zones. It is also prohibited to pass by riding off of the main-traveled portion of a roadway.

questions.question: When operating a motorcycle on a slippery surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerD: Use only the rear brake.
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, you should reduce your speed. Make certain to use both brakes when braking and avoid making sudden moves.

questions.question: Of the following, the colors that best allow riders to be seen are:
questions.answerB: Green and blue.
questions.answerC: Purple and gold.
questions.answerD: Black and white.
questions.explanation: To make yourself visible to others, wearing clothing that is bright orange, red, yellow, or green is best.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are designed to:
questions.answerB: Prevent brakes from activating if the roadway is dry.
questions.answerC: Apply brakes automatically.
questions.answerD: Warn you when your brake pad needs replacing.
questions.explanation: Some motorcycles are equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). ABS is designed to prevent skidding and wheel lock-up when motorcyclists are stopping in straight-line, panic situations. ABS operates when maximum pressure is applied to both the front and rear brake controls. If electronic sensors detect the possibility of a wheel lock, brake hydraulic pressure is released then re-applied to maintain maximum braking effectiveness.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a position that will allow the other driver to see you in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Assume the driver sees you.
questions.answerC: Ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a car, you should position yourself so you can be seen in the other driver's rearview mirror. Riding in the center portion of the lane will generally ensure that you will appear in the middle of their rearview mirror, where the driver is most likely to notice you.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerB: In front of the group.
questions.answerC: At the tail end of the group.
questions.answerD: Beside the leader.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, riders with less experience should be positioned toward the front of the group, just behind the leader. This will allow more experienced riders to keep an eye on them without forcing the inexperienced rider to lead the group.

questions.question: The gearshift lever is operated by:
questions.answerB: Your right foot.
questions.answerC: Your left hand.
questions.answerD: Your left foot.
questions.explanation: The gearshift lever of a motorcycle is located in front of the left footrest and is operated by the rider's left foot.

questions.question: Switching to a lower gear is also known as:
questions.answerB: Acceleration.
questions.answerC: Upshifting.
questions.answerD: Coasting.
questions.explanation: Shifting to a lower gear causes an effect similar to using the brakes. For this reason, downshifting is also known as engine braking.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Avoid other drivers' blind spots.
questions.answerC: Avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerD: Prevent access to an escape route.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: If you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings and your motorcycle begins to weave, you should:
questions.answerB: Steer in a weaving pattern.
questions.answerC: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the grooves.
questions.answerD: Move to the leftmost portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle may weave while riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, but this is generally not dangerous. If your motorcycle begins to weave, simply relax and proceed straight ahead at a steady speed. Trying to ride in a zigzag pattern to compensate for the weave will only increase the hazard.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerB: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.
